{{short description|American country singer and songwriter}} {{Use mdy dates|date=October 2019}} {{Infobox musical artist | name = Travis Meadows | image = | birth_name = | alias = | origin = | genre = {{flatlist| * [[Country music|Country]] }} | occupation = {{flatlist| * Singer * songwriter }} | years_active = 2007–present | associated_acts = {{flatlist| * [[Eric Church]] * [[Dierks Bentley]] * [[Frankie Ballard]] * [[Jake Owen]] * [[Blackberry Smoke]] * [[Levi Lowrey]] * [[Kenny Chesney]] }} }} '''Travis Meadows''' (born 1965) is an American [[country music]] singer and songwriter. He has released four albums and written a number of songs for other country artists. ==Early life== Meadows was born in 1965 in Mississippi, growing up in [[Jackson, Mississippi|Jackson]].{{cite web | url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/features/travis-meadows-songs-interview-20141008 | title=Nashville's Most Badass Songwriter Travis Meadows Shares Tragic Life Stories | publisher=Rolling Stone Country | date=October 8, 2015 | accessdate=August 20, 2015 | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150907042531/http://www.rollingstone.com/music/features/travis-meadows-songs-interview-20141008 | url-status=live | archivedate=September 7, 2015}} He began using drugs at an early age, and at 14 was diagnosed with bone cancer, which led to the loss of most of his right leg. ==Career== At the age of 16, he began playing in local bands, starting his musical career as a drummer before beginning to play the harmonica and guitar by the time he was 21. During his early 20s, he performed with blues musicians such as [[Sam Myers]], and moved to [[Gatlinburg, Tennessee|Gatlinburg]], where he began writing songs. In his mid-20s, Meadows became a Christian missionary and later a preacher, traveling around the United States and overseas, as well as writing and performing Christian music. By his late 30s, however, he had become disenchanted with the church, and moved to Nashville to pursue a songwriting career. He signed a contract with [[Universal Music Publishing]], releasing his debut album ''My life 101'' I'm 2007, but at the same time his life-long drinking and drug habits led to a multi-year descent into alcoholism and abuse. After four trips to rehab, he succeeded in regaining sobriety in 2010. In 2011, Meadows released a studio album, titled ''Killin' Uncle Buzzy'', written in 2010 while he was recovering from his alcohol addiction during his fourth period in rehab. According to Meadows, a counselor had suggested keeping a journal, which led to him writing songs instead. In 2013, after his songwriting contract with Universal expired, he began writing independently before signing with independent record label [[Kobalt Music]] and releasing a third album, ''Old Ghosts & Unfinished Business''.{{cite web | url=http://nashvillegab.com/2013/07/exclusive-interview-travis-meadows.html | title=Exclusive: Songwriter Travis Meadows on writing Dierks Bentley's "Riser," his tragic past and finding redemption | publisher=Nashville Gab | date=July 16, 2013 | accessdate=August 20, 2015}} In 2016, Meadows was featured in an episode of the television show ''American Elements''.{{Cite web|title = Travis Meadows : American Elements|url = http://www.carbontv.com/videos/0_6bxjfvyj|publisher = CarbonTV|access-date = February 10, 2016}} In 2017, Meadows released his fourth album, ''First Cigarette''. The album was produced by Jeremy Spillman and assisted by Jay Joyce, and is the first album by Meadows to receive label support.{{cite magazine |url=https://www.rollingstone.com/country/features/why-travis-meadows-is-nashvilles-favorite-underdog-w508798 |title=Why Songwriter Travis Meadows Is Nashville's Favorite Underdog |first=Dan |last=Hyman |date=October 13, 2017|magazine=Rolling Stone }} It is also his first album to appear on Billboard charts, reaching No. 21 on Heatseekers Albums and No. 48 on Independent Albums. It sold 1,100 copies in its debut week,{{cite news |url=http://roughstock.com/news/2017/10/42474-top-10-country-albums-sales-chart-october-24-2017 |title=TOP 10 Country Albums Sales Chart: October 24, 2017 |first= Matt |last= Bjorke |date= October 24, 2017 |work=Roughstock }} reaching No. 17 on Americana/Folk Album Sales and No. 34 on Country Album Sales.{{cite magazine |url=http://www.billboard.com/biz/charts/2017-11-04/country-album-sales |title=Country Album Sales|date=November 4, 2017 |magazine=Billboard }} In April 2021, [[Earache Records]] reissued ''Killin' Uncle Buzzy'' for the record's 10th Anniversary, including a limited edition clear vinyl. This was the first time the album had been available on vinyl and released by a label.{{Cite web|title=Travis Meadows - Killin' Uncle Buzzy|url=https://www.discogs.com/Travis-Meadows-Killin-Uncle-Buzzy/release/16943934|access-date=April 27, 2021|website=[[Discogs]]}}{{Cite web|date=March 12, 2021|title=10th Anniversary Reissue: Killin' Uncle Buzzy - Pre-order with Earache Records!|url=https://travismeadows.com/blogs/latest-news/posts/10th-anniversary-reissue-killin-uncle-buzzy-pre-order-with-earache-records|access-date=April 27, 2021|website=Travis Meadows}} ==Discography== ===Albums/EPs=== {| class="wikitable plainrowheaders" style="text-align:center;" |- ! rowspan="2" style="width:12em;"| Title ! rowspan="2" style="width:15em;"| Album details ! colspan="2"| Peak chart positions ! rowspan="2" style="width:8em;"| Sales |- style="font-size:smaller;" ! style="width:4em;"| [[Heatseekers Albums|US
